content.description:
P1. Approach mossy  junk 5.7. Climbing via the jungles of Bay tree bushes. 80 feet.

P2. Clean , very overhanging, leaning tight hands and than good hands crack. It looks from below easier than in fact it is. 100 feet 11c
content.protection:
3x #0.5 Cam ; 3x #0.75 cam; 3x #1 cam; 3x  #2 Cam

and small/medium gear for top of P1
content.location:
Right from Flight Attendant. The route is clearly seen from the approach trail, but it difficult to see it from the bottom of the crag.

The toe of the Buttress  is to the right of Flight Attendant and just LEFT of the approach pitch for the Viper (this is different than shown in Reid's book).

climbs.name: Minor Kinda Unit
climbs.fa: Dave Schultz, Ken Yager, Grant Hiskes (1986)

content.description: Starts in the big corner, then at a little roof move left to the left-trending ramp. Lots of big knobs, mostly face climbing with some liebacking at the end. It used to end at slings on  a block, but now you get an extra 10 feet of climbing to a new awkwardly placed bolted anchor. This climb is actually more fun than it looks from the ground, and it's the easiest route at the Jungle Gym.

climbs.name: Loyd's Lolly Pop
climbs.fa: Dave Schultz, Ken Yager, Grant Kiskes (Oct '86)

content.description:
To the right of The Jungle Book, in the main enclave area is a 60' tall horn of rock. This route climbs the left side of the feature. Doesn't look like much from the ground, but it's actually not a bad climb, though a bit short.

Start on top of a boulder and climb up and through an eroded overhang and into a low angle slot. At the top of the horn place a couple pieces as a directional then climb down and right to a bolted anchor.

This is one of the easier routes on the cliff. Start at the left side of the main enclave. Climb up a low angle ramp with cracks and then pass over a roof. Climb the steep fracture with lots of good handholds to reach a ledge with a boulder and rap slings. Belay here or link pitches with good rope management. Climb up the large ramp to the left, staying in the corner and passing by the bolted anchor which is out on the face to the left. Climb out the left side of another roof to a bolted anchor at a stance out on the arete.

The steep flared crack continuing straight up from the top of this route is a Jay Smith route and supposedly goes at 5.11.

Rappel to the ground with two ropes, or you can probably get down with one 70m (or maybe even a 60?) if you swing over to the anchor on Alamo. You can also rap over to anchor on Pygmy Village (5.12) if you want to set a toprope on that climb.
content.protection: Pro to 3" w/ some shoulder-length runners.

content.description: New closely-bolted sport climb that was squeezed in between Jungle Book and Loyd's. The crux is in the lower part. Then some fun jug pulling over the little roof in the middle. The upper section is contrived slab climbing just a couple feet left of the crack. At the last bolt move right to the new anchor at the top of Loyd's. Probably wasn't worth all the drilling, but it will no doubt become popular just because it's an easy sport climb.

climbs.name: Flight Attendant
climbs.fa: Ken Yager, Dave Schultz, and Grant Hiskes 10/86

content.description: A quite unique route. A wild move down low to a swing left around a roof. Then a good ledge for a rest. The left slanting crack that follows isn't too bad. Another good rest is above. The last 25 feet are steep and intimidating.
content.protection: Standard rack to 4". Maybe bring one extra orange alien size.
content.location:
The route is easily located once you find the Jungle Gym. Rappel the route.

We did this in mid October. One area on the approach had all the trees covered in Monarch butterflies. Thousands!

content.description:
To the right of

Loyd's Lolly Pop

, climbs up the face and finishes on the right side of the horn feature. High quality rock with nice features. A bit spicy but can also be toproped after doing the climb to the left.

Begin on the ground to the right of the boulder. Make some tricky moves to get started, then up and left to a piton. The seam takes tiny micro cams or small gear above and below the pin. Bringing two 000 C3's would help I think. Crux comes a bit after the piton, then you get some bomber gear, and then only a few more moves until you hit an easy crack on the right side of the horn. Good bolted anchor on the face above.

Really fun mixed trad and sport route. Crux is a 5.12 overhang protected with 4 bolts. Feels more like climbing overhanging limestone than anything reminiscent of Yosemite granite.

The climb shares the beginning of minor kinda unit (5.9) and goes straight up the dirty corner. Place pro and climb through low 5.10 moves up until where you're just below the first bolt. Make a few 10+ lieback moves to clip the bolt then venture into the steep overhang clipping three more bolts. At the fourth bolt, cut right and face traverse on huge jugs after the crux. Place gear to mitigate the runout or continue the traverse on 5.10ish jugs to meet the anchor of flight attendant. Clip the chains and enjoy the pump.

The moves are steep, fun and safe.
content.location: In between flight attendant and minor kinda unit. Prominent bushy corned left of flight attendant

content.description: Left of "Alamo", climb a crack, then face past 7 bolts. At the seventh bolt either move up right to the "Alamo" anchors, or move left and climb a corner to a two bolt anchor.

climbs.name: Alamo
climbs.fa: Al Swanson, Ken Yager, Dave Shultz, Grant Hiskes, 1986.

content.description:
This is up on the left side of this cliff.

From trees at the base, climb up to a bolt and dyno. Continue past two more bolts to a corner/crack. Follow this to an 85' rappel.
